segment.source: 4817(S) Auditing settings on object were changed.
segment.target: 4817(S) Auditing settings on object were changed.

segment.source: Describes security event 4817(S) Auditing settings on object were changed.
segment.target: Describes security event 4817(S) Auditing settings on object were changed.

segment.source: 4817(S): Auditing settings on object were changed.
segment.target: 4817(S): Auditing settings on object were changed.

segment.source: This event generates when the Global Object Access Auditing policy is changed on a computer.
segment.target: This event generates when the Global Object Access Auditing policy is changed on a computer.

segment.source: Separate events will be generated for “Registry” and “File system” policy changes.
segment.target: Separate events will be generated for “Registry” and “File system” policy changes.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7.

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that made a change to Global Object Access Auditing policy.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that made a change to Global Object Access Auditing policy.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that made a change to Global Object Access Auditing policy.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that made a change to Global Object Access Auditing policy.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Object Server Type = UnicodeString: has “LSA” value for this event.
segment.target: Object Server Type = UnicodeString: has “LSA” value for this event.

segment.source: Object Type Type = UnicodeString: The type of an object to which this event applies.
segment.target: Object Type Type = UnicodeString: The type of an object to which this event applies.

segment.source: The following table contains the list of the most common Object Types:
segment.target: The following table contains the list of the most common Object Types:

segment.source: Key – if “Registry” Global Object Access Auditing policy was changed.
segment.target: Key – if “Registry” Global Object Access Auditing policy was changed.

segment.source: File – if “File system” Global Object Access Auditing policy was changed.
segment.target: File – if “File system” Global Object Access Auditing policy was changed.

segment.source: Original Security Descriptor Type = UnicodeString: the old Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) value for the Global Object Access Auditing policy.
segment.target: Original Security Descriptor Type = UnicodeString: the old Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) value for the Global Object Access Auditing policy.

segment.source: Empty if Global Object Access Auditing policy SACL was not set.
segment.target: Empty if Global Object Access Auditing policy SACL was not set.

segment.source: New Security Descriptor Type = UnicodeString: the new Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) value for the Global Object Access Auditing policy.
segment.target: New Security Descriptor Type = UnicodeString: the new Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) value for the Global Object Access Auditing policy.

segment.source: Note The Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) defines string elements for enumerating information contained in the security descriptor.
segment.target: Note The Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) defines string elements for enumerating information contained in the security descriptor.

segment.source: SID of specific security principal, or reserved (pre-defined) value, for example: BA (BUILTINADMINISTRATORS), WD (Everyone), SY (LOCALSYSTEM), etc. See the list of possible values in the table below:
segment.target: SID of specific security principal, or reserved (pre-defined) value, for example: BA (BUILTINADMINISTRATORS), WD (Everyone), SY (LOCALSYSTEM), etc. See the list of possible values in the table below:

segment.source: "P” - SDDLPROTECTED, Inheritance from containers that are higher in the folder hierarchy are blocked.
segment.target: "P” - SDDLPROTECTED, Inheritance from containers that are higher in the folder hierarchy are blocked.

segment.source: "AI" - SDDLAUTOINHERITED, Inheritance is allowed, assuming that "P" Is not also set.
segment.target: "AI" - SDDLAUTOINHERITED, Inheritance is allowed, assuming that "P" Is not also set.

segment.source: "AR" - SDDLAUTOINHERITREQ, Child objects inherit permissions from this object.
segment.target: "AR" - SDDLAUTOINHERITREQ, Child objects inherit permissions from this object.

segment.source: "OA" - OBJECT ACCESS ALLOWED: only applies to a subset of the object(s).
segment.target: "OA" - OBJECT ACCESS ALLOWED: only applies to a subset of the object(s).

segment.source: "OD" - OBJECT ACCESS DENIED: only applies to a subset of the object(s).
segment.target: "OD" - OBJECT ACCESS DENIED: only applies to a subset of the object(s).

segment.source: "CI" - CONTAINER INHERIT: Child objects that are containers, such as directories, inherit the ACE as an explicit ACE.
segment.target: "CI" - CONTAINER INHERIT: Child objects that are containers, such as directories, inherit the ACE as an explicit ACE.

segment.source: "OI" - OBJECT INHERIT: Child objects that are not containers inherit the ACE as an explicit ACE.
segment.target: "OI" - OBJECT INHERIT: Child objects that are not containers inherit the ACE as an explicit ACE.

segment.source: "NP" - NO PROPAGATE: only immediate children inherit this ace.
segment.target: "NP" - NO PROPAGATE: only immediate children inherit this ace.

segment.source: "IO" - INHERITANCE ONLY: ace doesn’t apply to this object, but may affect children via inheritance.
segment.target: "IO" - INHERITANCE ONLY: ace doesn’t apply to this object, but may affect children via inheritance.

segment.source: rights: A hexadecimal string which denotes the access mask or reserved value, for example: FA (File All Access), FX (File Execute), FW (File Write), etc.
segment.target: rights: A hexadecimal string which denotes the access mask or reserved value, for example: FA (File All Access), FX (File Execute), FW (File Write), etc.

segment.source: accountsid: SID of specific security principal, or reserved value, for example: AN (Anonymous), WD (Everyone), SY (LOCALSYSTEM), etc. See the table above for more details.
segment.target: accountsid: SID of specific security principal, or reserved value, for example: AN (Anonymous), WD (Everyone), SY (LOCALSYSTEM), etc. See the table above for more details.

segment.source: For more information about SDDL syntax, see these articles: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc230374.aspx, https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/hardware/aa374892(v=vs.85).aspx.
segment.target: For more information about SDDL syntax, see these articles: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc230374.aspx, https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/hardware/aa374892(v=vs.85).aspx.

segment.source: For 4817(S): Auditing settings on object were changed.
segment.target: For 4817(S): Auditing settings on object were changed.

segment.source: If you use Global Object Access Auditing policies, then this event should be always monitored, especially on high value assets or computers.
segment.target: If you use Global Object Access Auditing policies, then this event should be always monitored, especially on high value assets or computers.

segment.source: If this change was not planned, investigate the reason for the change.
segment.target: If this change was not planned, investigate the reason for the change.

segment.source: If you don’t use Global Object Access Auditing policies, then this event should be always monitored because it indicates use of Global Object Access Auditing policies outside of your standard procedures.
segment.target: If you don’t use Global Object Access Auditing policies, then this event should be always monitored because it indicates use of Global Object Access Auditing policies outside of your standard procedures.
